required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Visual Prognosis in Non-Penetrating Corneal Blast Injuries
clinical_study.official_title: Visual Prognosis in Non-Penetrating Corneal Blast Injuries

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to assess visual quality of patients with non-penetrating, non-metallic, stable corneal foreign bodies. Visual quality will be assessed by examining visual acuity, wavefront analysis and contrast sensitivity. Drawings, photographs, and confocal microscopy will be used to document clinical examination of the cornea at baseline and on follow-up examinations.

clinical_study.condition: Corneal Foreign Body Following Blast Injury

intervention.intervention_name: Visual quality of patients with corneal eye injuries
intervention.description: Visual quality of patients with corneal eye injuries

study_pop.textblock: US Army patients age 18 years and older prsenting with corneal foreign bodies from non-penetrating ocular blast injuries

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Informed consent
- Access to medical care at Walter Reed Army Medical Center
- Age 18 years or older
- Corneal foreign bodies from blast injuries
- Available for evaluation at Walter Reed
Exclusion Criteria:
- Residual, recurrent or active ocular disease in the designated eye as determined by exam and history.
- Penetrating ocular trauma or injury to the posterior segment
- Prior history of ocular surgery
- Any physical or mental impairment that would preclude participation in any of the examinations.
- Any ocular abnormality other than corneal foreign bodies that have any impact on vision (i.e. other abnormalities from trauma such as retinal detachment, corneal laceration, traumatic cataract, or abnormalities unrelated to trauma such as herpes.

overall_official.affiliation: Ophthalmology Service, Walter Reed Army Medical Center
